My Home Safety

Managing your home for fire safety and prevention is an important part of reducing the risks of potential fire and personal injury. Most fires occur unexpectedly because they are caused by the most ordinary, everyday items you would normally consider safe. A stove burner, a candle, a hairdryer and many more frequently used home appliances can become a silent fire hazard.

Use our simple interactive My Home Safety model. Roll over the different areas of the house, you will be shown links to valuable fire safety information organized by state and federal fire safety authorities.

  • The garage
  • The entrance
  • The bedroom
  • The attic
  • The bathroom
  • The utility room
  • The kitchen
  • The living room
  • The basement

My House

Your House

How safe is your home? HomeHero’s™ interactive My Home Safety model will help you explore some of the more important fire hazards you might find in your home. Click on any room for specific information that is meant to educate you and your family on how to deal with the many hazards that can be hidden in your home.

The Garage

Reducing the fire hazards in your garage is a great excuse to clean it up! Your garage will look better and you will feel better knowing you have reduced certain fire risks. Click on the Garage to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Entrance

Today’s busy families seldom have time to think about our home’s halls and entrance ways. Now is a good time to recognize these areas and how they fit into your fire safety plan. Click on the Front Door of our interactive house to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Bedroom

Do all your bedrooms have working smoke and carbon monoxide alarms? Here are some fire safety ideas on how to reduce risk and be better prepared to prevent fires. Click on the Bedroom to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Attic

Whether you use your attic for a storage area, or expand its usage into an extra play room for the family, here are some ideas on what to look for in your attic when you make your regular home safety inspection. Click on the Attic to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Bathroom

If you have more things to plug in, than places to plug into, here are some important safety tips to consider for your family bathrooms. Click on the Bathroom to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Utility Room

The size of a room doesn’t matter when it comes to fire hazards. Check our laundry list of the hazards you should be aware of in your laundry or utility room. Click on the Utility Room to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Kitchen

When it comes to home fires, your kitchen is the most dangerous room in the house. Learn how to avoid simple mistakes, and how to reduce the risks. Click on the Kitchen to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Living Room

The living/family room has become a multipurpose area. Here are some suggestions for fire safety practices you can share with your family and make part of your daily routines. Click on the Living/Family room to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

The Basement

Heating equipment, including furnaces and hot water heaters, are a major source of home fires. Investigate the fire hazards you might find in your basement, and how to avoid them. Click on the Basement to see and learn more about home fire prevention.

HomeHero™ wants you to have the peace of mind that comes from knowing your family is more educated and better prepared to handle a fire emergency. Being aware of the common household dangers is the first step you can take to ensure you and your family will know the right preventative actions to remove or reduce fire risks. Learn about home fire safety systems.

Each room of your home has its own unique fire safety risks. Fire safety authorities suggest that by exercising good safety habits and simple prevention measures can minimize your fire hazards. Take the time to review this information and explore some of the sites we have recommended to learn more about how you can remove risks for potential fire hazards and protect your family and property.
